triples.statement: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern on January 30, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11, 2020.
The WHO declared the end of the public health emergency caused by COVID-19 in May 2023.
As of 2024, experts were uncertain if the situation still qualified as a pandemic.
Varying definitions of a pandemic result in different conclusions about when one ends.
As of December 5, 2025, COVID-19 has resulted in over 7.1 million confirmed deaths and an estimated 18.2 to 33.5 million deaths.
The meaning of the term "pandemic" has been challenged during the COVID-19 pandemic, as it has been during other pandemics.
The end of an epidemic can be seen as a social phenomenon, not merely a biological one.
Time magazine reported in March 2024 that expert opinions vary on whether COVID-19 is endemic or pandemic, and noted that the WHO's website continued to classify the disease as a pandemic.
WHO Director-General Tedros Ghebreyesus explained that COVID-19 stands for corona (CO), virus (VI), disease (D), and 19 for the year the outbreak was first identified.
The practice of naming variants based on where they were identified, such as the "Indian variant" for Delta, is no longer common.
There have been 778,852,659 confirmed cases of COVID-19.
There have been 7,102,566 confirmed deaths from COVID-19.
Many early cases were linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, but it is possible that human-to-human transmission began earlier.
Molecular clock analysis suggests that the first cases likely occurred between October and November 2019.
The scientific consensus is that the virus most likely has a zoonotic origin from bats or another closely related mammal.
Official "case" counts refer to the number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 according to official protocols, regardless of whether they had symptoms.
Early in the pandemic, many countries had official policies against testing people with only mild symptoms.
A retrospective cohort study in China concluded that children and adults had an equal likelihood of being infected.
Preliminary results from a study on April 9, 2020, in Gangelt, Germany, found that 15% of a population sample tested positive for antibodies.
Screening of pregnant women in New York City and blood donors in the Netherlands revealed positive antibody test rates that suggested higher infection numbers than officially reported.
Seroprevalence-based estimates are considered conservative because some studies indicate that individuals with mild symptoms may not develop detectable antibodies.
By April 14, 2022, more than 500 million COVID-19 cases had been confirmed globally.
A WHO study shows global excess and reported COVID-19 deaths, as well as deaths per 100,000 people.
The first confirmed death from COVID-19 was in Wuhan on January 9, 2020.
COVID-19 death counts vary by region and time due to factors including testing volume, healthcare quality, government response, and population characteristics.
Multiple measures are used to quantify mortality.
These counts exclude deaths where no test was administered.
Countries like Belgium increase their death counts by including suspected cases, even those without a test.
These excess deaths include those resulting from healthcare system constraints and public reluctance to seek medical care.
More research could help differentiate between deaths directly caused by COVID-19 and those from the pandemic's indirect consequences.
Some deaths occurred because people with other conditions were unable to access medical services.
These excess death figures do not account for measures like 'years of potential life lost' and suggest the pandemic may have been the leading cause of death in 2021.
The time from the onset of symptoms to death ranges from 6 to 41 days, with a typical duration of about 14 days.
The elderly and individuals with underlying conditions face the greatest risk of mortality.
The IFR is expressed in percentage points.
This metric is also referred to as the infection fatality risk in other studies.
A November 2020 review in Nature reported a median range of 0.24% to 1.49% for population-weighted IFRs in various countries, not including deaths in elderly care facilities.
Reviews have been conducted comparing the fatality rate of the COVID-19 pandemic with previous ones, such as MERS-CoV.
As of May 2023, the WHO had downgraded all variants of concern to 'previously circulating' as they were no longer detected in new infections.
Omicron sub-lineages (BA.1 – BA.5) were considered separate variants of concern (VoCs) by the WHO until they were downgraded in March 2023 because they were no longer widely circulating.
As of September 24, 2024, the WHO designated BA.2.86 and JN.1 as variants of interest, and JN.1.7, KP.2, KP.3, KP.3.1.1, JN.1.18, LB.1, and XEC as variants under monitoring.
The symptoms of COVID-19 vary, with a range from mild to severe illness.
Common symptoms of COVID-19 include headache, loss of smell and taste, nasal congestion, runny nose, cough, muscle pain, sore throat, fever, diarrhoea, and breathing difficulties.

Three common symptom clusters have been identified: a respiratory cluster (cough, sputum, shortness of breath, fever), a musculoskeletal cluster (muscle/joint pain, headache, fatigue), and a digestive cluster (abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea).
SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the coronavirus family of viruses.
Coronaviruses infect humans, other mammals (including livestock and companion animals), and avian species.
SARS-CoV-2 is the seventh known coronavirus to infect people, following 229E, NL63, OC43, HKU1, MERS-CoV, and the original SARS-CoV.
The standard method for testing for SARS-CoV-2 is a nucleic acid test, which detects viral RNA fragments.
Because these tests detect RNA and not the infectious virus, their ability to determine how long a patient is infectious is limited.
The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.

Preventive measures to reduce the chances of COVID-19 infection include vaccination, staying home, avoiding crowds, social distancing, wearing masks, ventilating indoor spaces, managing exposure durations, frequent hand washing, practicing good respiratory hygiene, and avoiding touching one's face with unwashed hands.

Healthcare authorities advise individuals diagnosed with or suspecting they have COVID-19 to stay home except for medical care, call providers in advance, wear a face mask, cover coughs and sneezes, wash hands regularly, and avoid sharing personal household items.
This knowledge accelerated the development of various vaccine platforms during early 2020.
The initial focus of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines was on preventing symptomatic and severe illness.
COVID-19 vaccines are widely credited for their role in reducing the severity and death caused by COVID-19.
A June 2022 study estimated that COVID-19 vaccines prevented an additional 14.4 million to 19.8 million deaths in 185 countries and territories from December 8, 2020, to December 8, 2021.
The WHO report indicated that inequitable distribution is not unique to COVID-19 vaccines and that less economically strong countries struggle to obtain vaccines.
On November 14, 2022, the first inhalable vaccine, developed by CanSino Biologics, was introduced in Shanghai, China.
For the first two years of the pandemic, no specific and effective treatment or cure for COVID-19 was available.
The European Medicines Agency's CHMP approved the oral antiviral protease inhibitor Paxlovid in 2021 to treat adult patients.
Good personal hygiene and a healthy diet are also recommended.
Supportive care for severe cases includes symptom relief, fluid therapy, oxygen support, prone positioning, and support for other vital organs.
The use of the glucocorticoid dexamethasone is recommended to reduce mortality in patients with low oxygen levels.
Prolonged prothrombin time and elevated C-reactive protein levels upon hospital admission are linked to a severe course of COVID-19 and transfer to an ICU.
Between 5% and 50% of COVID-19 patients experience long COVID, a condition defined by long-term consequences that persist beyond the typical recovery period.
Mitigation goals include delaying and reducing the peak burden on healthcare (flattening the curve) and lessening overall cases and health impacts.
Increasing healthcare capacity by adding more beds, personnel, and equipment, a strategy known as "raising the line," helps to meet increased demand.

Experts distinguish between elimination strategies ("zero-COVID"), which aim to completely stop community spread, and mitigation strategies ("flattening the curve"), which try to reduce the virus's societal effects while tolerating some transmission.
These initial strategies can be pursued sequentially or at the same time during the acquired immunity phase, which is achieved through natural and vaccine-induced immunity.

The zero-COVID strategy employs public health measures like contact tracing, mass testing, border quarantine, lockdowns, and software to halt community transmission of COVID-19 upon detection, aiming to reach zero infections and resume normal activities.
Successful mitigation delays and reduces the peak of an epidemic, a process known as "flattening the epidemic curve".
Flattening the curve reduces the risk of overwhelming health services and allows more time for the development of vaccines and treatments.
Drastic actions like quarantining entire populations and imposing strict travel bans were attempted in various jurisdictions.
Singapore's government response included "circuit breaker lockdowns," financial support for those affected, and large fines for quarantine violations.

Contact tracing seeks to identify and screen recent contacts of newly infected people, with the traditional method involving requesting a contact list from the infected individual and then calling or visiting those contacts.
Contact tracing was used extensively during the 2014 Western African Ebola virus epidemic.
An alternative approach to contact tracing involves collecting location data from mobile devices to identify significant contacts of infected individuals, which has led to privacy concerns.
On April 10, 2020, Google and Apple announced an initiative for contact tracing that preserves privacy.
In Europe and the US, Palantir Technologies was an initial provider of COVID-19 tracking services.
Due to supply chain capacity limitations, some manufacturers began 3D printing materials such as nasal swabs and ventilator parts.
An Italian startup received legal threats for alleged patent infringement after reverse-engineering and printing one hundred requested ventilator valves overnight.
Novel devices such as ear savers, non-invasive ventilation helmets, and ventilator splitters were created.
Human-to-human transmission may have been occurring before the outbreak was discovered.
A retrospective analysis indicated that by December 2019, cases in Hubei had increased to 60 by December 20 and at least 266 by December 31.
On January 3, eight doctors, including ophthalmologist Li Wenliang, were detained by police for "spreading false rumours".
Initially, the number of cases doubled approximately every seven and a half days.
Wuhan was a transport hub and major rail interchange.
The report also advocated for testing, given the outbreak's "pandemic potential".
On January 31, the first published modelling study warned of inevitable "independent self-sustaining outbreaks in major cities globally" and called for "large-scale public health interventions".
By January 31, Italy had indicated its first confirmed infections occurred in two tourists from China.
On March 11, the WHO announced its assessment that the situation could be characterized as a pandemic.
On March 19, Italy surpassed China as the country with the most reported deaths.
By March 26, the United States had surpassed China and Italy as the country with the highest number of confirmed infections.
Genomic analysis indicated that most of New York's confirmed infections came from Europe, rather than directly from Asia.
In October, the WHO reported that an estimated one in ten people worldwide (780 million) may have been infected, while only 35 million infections had been confirmed.
On the same day, Novavax submitted an FDA Fast Track application for their vaccine.
As of December 13, 1,108 infections of the new variant had been confirmed in the UK.
On February 4, 2020, US Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar waived liability for vaccine manufacturers in all cases except those involving "willful misconduct".
By 2 January, the Alpha variant, first discovered in the UK, had been identified in 33 countries.
The Gamma variant was first identified on 6 January in Japanese travellers returning from Brazil.
On 12 March, several countries stopped using the Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine due to blood clotting problems, specifically cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST).
On 20 March, the WHO and European Medicines Agency found no link to thrombosis, which led several countries to resume administering the vaccine.
In March, the WHO reported that an animal host was the most likely origin of the virus, without ruling out other possibilities.
On 10 November, Germany advised against the Moderna vaccine for people under 30 because of a possible association with myocarditis.
The Omicron variant was detected in South Africa on 24 November, and a few days later the WHO declared it a variant of concern (VoC).
The Omicron variant is more infectious than the Delta variant.
On January 1, 2022, Europe surpassed 100 million COVID-19 cases during a surge of the Omicron variant.
By March 6, 2022, the total worldwide death count from COVID-19 was reported to have surpassed 6 million.
On October 21, 2022, the United States surpassed 99 million COVID-19 cases, the highest number of any country.
By October 30, 2022, the global daily death toll from COVID-19 was 424, the lowest figure since March 12, 2020.
November 17, 2022, was the three-year anniversary of the first detection of COVID-19 by health officials in China.
On December 3, 2022, the WHO indicated that at least 90% of the global population had some level of immunity to SARS-CoV-2.
The WHO's Europe office stated on January 10 that the recent viral surge in China did not pose an "immediate threat."
On January 16, the WHO recommended that China should monitor its excess mortality to better understand the impact of COVID-19.
On January 30, three years after its initial declaration, the WHO confirmed that COVID-19 still qualified as a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC).
On May 5, the WHO downgraded COVID-19 from a global health emergency, but still considered it a pandemic.
The WHO does not officially declare when pandemics are over.
In a press conference, WHO Director-General Tedros stated that the reduced threat from COVID-19 had enabled most countries to resume pre-pandemic life.
In September, the WHO reported observing "concerning" trends in COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations, but noted that analysis was difficult as many countries had stopped recording case statistics.
As of March 26, 2020, 1.7 billion people worldwide were under some form of lockdown.
By the first week of April, the number of people under lockdown increased to 3.9 billion, which was more than half the world's population.
A study from February 2021 found that protests against restrictions were likely to directly increase the spread of the virus.
By the end of 2021, Asia's COVID-19 peak occurred in May 2021, aligning in time and level with the global peak.
Cumulatively, Asia had experienced only half the global average of COVID-19 cases.
China implemented a containment strategy with strict lockdowns to stop the spread of the virus.
China's zero-COVID policy was largely successful in containing the initial waves of infection.
In 2022, during the Omicron variant waves, China was one of the few countries still pursuing a zero-COVID strategy.
About half of India's reported cases were in six cities: Mumbai, Delhi, Ahmedabad, Chennai, Pune, and Kolkata.
After the lockdown, the Indian government launched the Aarogya Setu app for contact tracing and vaccine distribution management.
India's vaccination program was regarded as the world's largest and most successful, with over 90% of citizens receiving a first dose and 65% receiving a second dose.
A second wave of COVID-19 in India in April 2021 put a strain on healthcare services.
By October 21, 2021, India had administered over 1 billion vaccine doses.
Tehran Metro trains were disinfected to prevent COVID-19 transmission, a measure also adopted in other countries.
In February 2020, Iran became a center of the pandemic.
By February 28, over ten countries had traced their outbreaks to Iran, suggesting the outbreak was more severe than the 388 cases officially reported.
The Iranian Parliament closed on March 3, 2020, after 23 of its 290 members tested positive for COVID-19.
By March 17, 2020, at least twelve current or former Iranian politicians and government officials had died from COVID-19.
The fifth wave of the pandemic in Iran peaked in August 2021, with over 400 deaths in a single day.
Military bases in South Korea were quarantined after three soldiers tested positive.
South Korea implemented what was considered the world's largest and most organized screening program, which involved isolating infected individuals and conducting contact tracing and quarantine.
By March 17, 2020, every European country had confirmed a case of COVID-19, and all except Vatican City had reported at least one death.
Italy was the first European country to have a major outbreak in early 2020 and became the first country in the world to implement a national lockdown.
More than 250 million people in Europe were in lockdown by March 18, 2020.
In late 2021, Europe once again became the pandemic's epicentre, despite the deployment of COVID-19 vaccines.
The Italian outbreak started on January 31, 2020, after two Chinese tourists in Rome tested positive for SARS-CoV-2.
All sports were suspended for a minimum of one month.
On March 11, Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte ordered the closure of almost all commercial activities, excluding supermarkets and pharmacies.
The first wave subsided by April 19, with the 7-day death count falling to 433.
To manage the second wave, the Italian government implemented new restrictive rules on October 13.
Italy's confirmed infections exceeded 1 million on November 10.
It was reported on November 23 that the second wave had caused some hospitals to cease admitting new patients.
The first confirmed case of the virus in Spain was on January 31, 2020, involving a German tourist on La Gomera in the Canary Islands.
Genetic analysis later revealed that at least 15 different strains of the virus were imported into Spain, with community transmission starting by mid-February.
By September 2021, Spain had one of the highest vaccination rates, with 76% of its population fully vaccinated and 79% having received at least one dose.
Italy ranked second in vaccination rates at 75%.
Sweden's response differed from most European countries as it largely remained open.
Sweden's strategy was centered on long-term measures, assuming the virus would spread again after any lockdown, leading to the same outcome.
By the end of June, Sweden was no longer experiencing excess mortality.
The restrictions in England were of a shorter duration compared to those in the other UK countries.
The UK government began enforcing social distancing and quarantine measures on March 18, 2020.
On March 20, the UK government ordered the closure of all leisure establishments and pledged to prevent unemployment.
Most non-essential businesses were ordered to close.
It was reported on April 24, 2020, that a promising vaccine trial had started in England, with the government committing over £50 million to research.
On December 2, 2020, the UK was the first developed nation to approve the Pfizer vaccine, making 800,000 doses immediately available.
In August 2022, reports indicated a decline in viral infection cases in the UK.
The virus arrived in the United States on 13 January 2020.
By March 25, all North American countries had reported COVID-19 cases, and by April 16, all North American territories had reported cases.

According to Our World in Data, the United States has reported 103,436,829 confirmed cases and 1,228,289 deaths, the highest total of any country and the nineteenth-highest per capita death rate globally.
The number of US deaths from COVID-19 in 2021 was higher than in 2020.
The Food and Drug Administration officially approved the first COVID-19 vaccine on August 23, 2021.
By November 18, 2022, the COVID variants BQ.1 and BQ.1.1 had become dominant in the U.S., even as overall cases had declined.
COVID-19 cases surged across Canada, particularly in British Columbia, Alberta, Quebec, and Ontario, leading to the creation of the travel-restricted Atlantic Bubble.
A report on November 11, 2022, indicated that Canadian health authorities observed a surge in influenza and expected a rise in COVID-19 during the winter.
On May 22, 2020, the WHO declared South America the epicentre of the pandemic, citing the rapid increase of infections in Brazil.
Due to a shortage of testing and medical facilities, the outbreak is believed to be far larger than official numbers show.
The virus was confirmed to have spread to Brazil on February 25, 2020, when a man from São Paulo who had travelled to Italy tested positive.
On June 19, 2020, Brazil reported its one millionth case and nearly 49,000 deaths.
One estimate of under-reporting was 22.62% of total reported COVID-19 mortality in 2020.
The first confirmed COVID-19 case in sub-Saharan Africa was announced in Nigeria at the end of February 2020.
Within three months, the virus spread across the continent, with Lesotho, the last African sovereign state to be virus-free, reporting its first case on May 13, 2020.
By May 26, it seemed most African countries were experiencing community transmission, though testing capacity was limited.
Many African countries implemented preventive measures, including travel restrictions, flight cancellations, and event cancellations.
Africa reported lower death rates from COVID-19 than other, more economically developed regions.
In early June 2021, Africa experienced a third wave of COVID-19 infections, with cases increasing in 14 countries.
More than sixteen African countries, including Malawi and Senegal, recorded an increase in new cases.
The COVID-19 pandemic reached Oceania on January 25, 2020, with the first confirmed case reported in Melbourne, Australia.
The virus subsequently spread to other parts of the region.
Due to the high transmissibility of the Delta variant, the Australian states of New South Wales and Victoria abandoned their eradication efforts by August 2021.
In early October 2021, New Zealand also gave up its elimination strategy.
By early March 2022, as daily cases surpassed 1,000, Western Australia abandoned its eradication strategy and opened its borders.
By April 2022, despite record case numbers, Australian jurisdictions gradually removed restrictions including close contact isolation, mask wearing, and density limits.
The nationwide aircraft mask mandate was removed, and case reporting shifted from daily to weekly.
On September 14, the COVID-19 disaster payment for individuals in mandatory isolation was extended.
By September 22, all Australian states had ended mask mandates on public transport; Victoria's mandate had been in place for about 800 days.
On September 30, 2022, Australian leaders declared the end of the emergency response and announced the termination of isolation requirements.
These changes were attributed in part to high levels of 'hybrid immunity' and low case numbers.

The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNSC) was criticized for its slow response, particularly regarding the UN's global ceasefire aimed at providing humanitarian access to conflict zones.
The pandemic caused a global economic shock, with particularly severe damage in the United States, Europe, and Latin America.
During the pandemic, many countries and regions imposed restrictions such as quarantines and entry bans for citizens, recent travelers to affected areas, or all travelers.
As the virus spread globally, the effectiveness of travel restrictions was questioned.
A study found that travel restrictions had only a modest effect on the initial spread of the virus unless they were combined with other infection prevention and control measures.
Canada, the United States, Japan, India, Sri Lanka, Australia, France, Argentina, Germany and Thailand were among the first countries to repatriate their citizens.
Brazil and New Zealand evacuated their own nationals and citizens of other countries.
The US announced on February 15 that it would evacuate Americans from the Diamond Princess cruise ship, and on February 21, Canada evacuated 129 of its citizens from the vessel.
In early March, the Indian government started repatriating its citizens from Iran.
On March 20, the United States began to withdraw some troops from Iraq.
On February 27, 2020, concerns about the outbreak led to US stock indexes posting their sharpest declines since 2008.
Airlines cancelled flights, and the British regional airline Flybe collapsed.
The cruise line industry was severely impacted, and train stations and ferry ports were closed.
Hundreds of millions of jobs were lost, including over 40 million in the US.
A report by Yelp indicated that about 60% of US businesses that closed will remain permanently shut.
The International Labour Organization (ILO) reported that global income from work dropped by 10.7%, or $3.5 trillion, in the first nine months of 2020.
Panic buying was caused by perceived threats, scarcity, fear of the unknown, coping behaviors, and social psychological factors like social influence and trust.
Supply shortages were caused by disruptions to factory and logistic operations and were made worse by supply chain issues such as factory and port shutdowns, along with labor shortages.
The poorest countries, however, saw a sharp rise in food prices, which reached their highest point since the start of the pandemic.
The Agricultural Commodity Price Index stabilized in the third quarter but was still 17% higher than in January 2021.
In contrast, there was a surplus of petroleum products early in the pandemic because demand for gasoline and other products fell due to decreased travel.
Demand for energy was especially high in Asia.
By March 2020, cultural institutions worldwide, including museums, libraries, and performance venues, had closed indefinitely, with events and performances cancelled or postponed.
The pandemic impacted political systems, leading to the suspension of legislative activities, the isolation or death of politicians, and the rescheduling of elections.
The COVID-19 pandemic and the response to it by Brazilian politicians resulted in widespread panic, confusion, and pessimism in Brazil.

President Bolsonaro disregarded WHO-recommended mitigation techniques, downplayed the virus's risks, promoted economic activity, spread misinformation about public health measures, and distributed unproven treatments like hydroxychloroquine and ivermectin.
A number of federal health ministers resigned or were dismissed after refusing to implement President Bolsonaro's policies.
Brazil was heavily affected by the Delta and Omicron variants.
At the peak of the outbreak in spring 2021, more than 3,000 Brazilians were dying each day.
Some commentators claimed the dismissal of provincial administrators was intended to protect CCP General Secretary Xi Jinping.
The US intelligence community claimed that China intentionally under-reported its number of COVID-19 cases.
In early March 2020, the Italian government criticized the EU for a lack of solidarity with Italy.

On 22 March 2020, after a phone call with Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered the Russian army to send military medics, disinfection vehicles, and other medical equipment to Italy.

In early April, Norway and EU member states such as Romania and Austria began to provide aid by sending medical staff and disinfectant, and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen officially apologized to Italy.
On April 20, 2020, anti-lockdown protesters rallied at the Ohio Statehouse.
Starting in mid-April 2020, protestors objected to government-imposed closures of businesses and restrictions on personal movement and assembly.
The Kaiser Family Foundation estimated that preventable hospitalizations of unvaccinated Americans cost US$13.8 billion in the second half of 2021.
Protests also occurred in the United States regarding vaccine mandates.
In January 2022, the US Supreme Court invalidated an OSHA rule that required vaccination or testing for all companies with more than 100 employees.
The number of journalists imprisoned or detained increased globally, with some detentions being related to the pandemic.
The Iranian government was significantly impacted by the virus, with about two dozen parliament members and political figures becoming infected.
On March 14, 2020, Iranian president Hassan Rouhani wrote a public letter to world leaders asking for help due to a lack of access to international markets.
Saudi Arabia, which began a military intervention in Yemen in March 2015, declared a ceasefire.
Diplomatic relations between Japan and South Korea worsened.
South Korea criticized Japan's quarantine efforts as "ambiguous and passive" after Japan announced travelers from South Korea must quarantine for two weeks.
Some commentators expressed concern that emergency legislation could allow governments to strengthen their grip on power.
In Hungary, the parliament voted to allow Prime Minister Viktor Orbán to rule by decree indefinitely, suspend parliament and elections, and punish those considered to have spread false information.
In India, journalists who criticized the government's response were arrested or issued warnings by police and authorities.
The pandemic disrupted global food systems at a time when hunger was rising, with an estimated 690 million people lacking food security in 2019.
Access to food decreased due to falling incomes, lost remittances, and disruptions to food production.
In some cases, food prices rose.
According to the WHO, 811 million people were undernourished in 2020, an outcome likely related to the fallout from COVID-19.
School closures impacted students, teachers, and families, leading to significant economic and societal consequences.
The impact was more severe for disadvantaged children.
Many countries, including Bangladesh, granted automatic promotion to candidates for public examinations.
The Higher Education Policy Institute reported that about 63% of students said their mental health worsened because of the pandemic.
The head of cardiology at the University of Arizona expressed concern that some people were dying at home due to fear of going to the hospital.
People experiencing strokes and appendicitis were less likely to seek medical treatment.
Many people were impacted by medical supply shortages.
Following the relaxation of public health measures, North America and Europe saw a surge in respiratory viruses and coinfections in adults and children in late 2022.
By mid-December 2022, 19 children in the UK had died from Strep A, and the infection wave was spreading to North America and Mainland Europe.
The B/Yamagata lineage of influenza B may have become extinct in 2020/2021 due to measures taken during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Since March 2020, no naturally occurring cases of the B/Yamagata lineage have been confirmed.
In 2023, the WHO determined that protection against the Yamagata lineage was no longer needed in the seasonal flu vaccine, thereby reducing the targeted lineages from four to three.
Images from the NASA Earth Observatory show a significant drop in NO2 pollution levels in Wuhan when comparing early 2019 to early 2020.
During the "anthropause," there was a decrease in fossil fuel use, a decline in resource consumption, and improved waste disposal, which resulted in less pollution.
A wide variety of mostly mammalian species, both in captivity and in the wild, have been found to be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, with some experiencing very high rates of fatal outcomes.
Both farmed and wild mink have developed severe and highly symptomatic COVID-19 infections, with one study reporting a mortality rate as high as 35–55%.

An August 2023 study confirmed that white-tailed deer are a disease reservoir, observing that SARS-CoV-2 evolves three times faster in deer than in humans and that infection rates were still high, even in areas with little human contact.
The image depicts a socially distanced homeless encampment in San Francisco, California, in May 2020.
Increased prejudice, xenophobia, and racism directed at people of Chinese and East Asian descent were documented worldwide.
People of Asian descent in Europe and North America reported a rise in racially motivated abuse and assaults due to the pandemic.
Limited digital literacy also made the elderly more susceptible to isolation, depression, and loneliness.

In a 2021 correspondence in The Lancet, German epidemiologist Günter Kampf described the negative impacts of stigmatizing unvaccinated people, pointing out that vaccinated individuals also contribute significantly to transmission.

In response, American bioethicist Arthur Caplan argued that criticizing the unvaccinated for straining resources and prolonging the pandemic is not stigmatization but rather deserved moral condemnation.
Italy's restrictions included mandatory vaccination for those over 50 and for the use of public transport.
Hackers, cybercriminals, and scammers exploited the changes brought by the pandemic to launch new online attacks.
In some countries, education temporarily moved from in-person attendance to video conferencing.
Massive layoffs led to the contraction of the airline, travel, hospitality, and other industries.
A poll by Catalyst found that 68% of employees globally believed their companies' COVID-19 workplace policies were performative and not genuine.
According to a Gallup poll, the percentage of US employees working fully remotely increased from 4% before the pandemic to 43% in May 2020.
The shift to remote work was more pronounced among white-collar workers, increasing from 6% to 65% in the same period.
The trend of remote work continued in later stages of the pandemic, as many workers opted to stay remote even after workplaces reopened.
The exodus of remote workers caused a decline in office real estate value in high-cost, dense urban areas.

By May 2023, some US white-collar workplaces used performance review penalties and indirect incentives to encourage employees to return to the office, citing increased layoffs and productivity concerns.
Many comparisons were made between the COVID-19 and 1918 influenza pandemics, including the development of anti-mask movements, widespread misinformation, and the impact of socioeconomic disparities.
Some religious leaders decried what they perceived as violations of religious freedom.
In other cases, religious identity was a beneficial health factor, as it increased compliance with public health measures and protected against the negative mental wellbeing effects of isolation.
Some news organizations removed their online paywalls for some or all of their articles and posts related to the pandemic.
As part of the National Institutes of Health's COVID-19 Public Health Emergency Initiative, many scientific publishers provided pandemic-related journal articles to the public free of charge.
An estimate from University of Rome researchers found that 89.5% of COVID-19-related papers were open access, compared to an average of 48.8% for the ten most deadly human diseases.
The proportion of papers published on preprint servers before peer review increased dramatically.
In March 2020, the WHO declared an "infodemic" of incorrect information.
Cognitive biases, such as confirmation bias, are linked to conspiracy beliefs, including COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy.
The pandemic was incorporated into the narratives of both existing and new television series, with mixed results.
Writing for The New York Times on December 16, 2020, about the BBC sitcom Pandemonium, David Segal questioned whether people were ready to find humor in the COVID-19 pandemic.
The pandemic led some people to seek peaceful escapism in media, while others were drawn to fictional pandemics, such as zombie apocalypses, as another form of escapism.
Common themes in media included contagion, isolation, and loss of control.

According to Spotify listenership data, as people used music to cope with pandemic-related emotions, the classical, ambient, and children's genres grew in popularity, while pop, country, and dance remained relatively stable.
A review in March 2022 declared that a transition to endemic status was "inevitable".
An article in Human Genomics from June 2022 stated the pandemic was still "raging" but that it was time to explore transitioning to an endemic phase.
A review in June 2022 predicted that the virus causing COVID-19 would become the fifth endemic seasonal human coronavirus.
A February 2023 review concluded that the COVID-19 virus would become seasonal and, like the common cold, cause less severe disease for most people.
A 2023 review stated that the transition to endemic COVID-19 could take years or decades.
On May 5, 2023, the WHO declared the pandemic was no longer a public health emergency of international concern.
The WHO told Full Fact it was unlikely to declare the pandemic over soon, citing the cholera pandemic, which it considers to have been ongoing since 1961.
Epidemics and pandemics typically end when a disease becomes endemic and is accepted as a manageable part of normal life.
In March 2024, experts consulted by Time magazine noted that COVID-19 was still circulating and causing disease, but were uncertain if it should still be called a pandemic.
High inflation rates in several countries had global impacts, particularly affecting developing nations.
In 2022, the pandemic caused an increase in occupational burnout in Australia.
Some corporations tried to force workers to return to on-site work, while others embraced the remote work model.
A "travel boom" led to a faster-than-anticipated recovery in air travel, with the aviation industry becoming profitable in 2023 for the first time since 2019.
Some predicted that the travel boom would begin to slow down due to economic issues.
While efforts to increase vaccination rates for some diseases were successful, the UN observed that post-pandemic measles vaccinations were still lagging.
A number of African countries experienced a drop in vaccinations because of pandemic-related misinformation spreading to other health topics.
